attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/coreload|@coreload>: I yearn for higher-level, semantic, knowledge-based, domain-driven, data-driven systems development. attachments.text: I yearn for higher-level, semantic, knowledge-based, domain-driven, data-driven systems development. Too much code is needed for too little benefit whether or not the compiler has a type checker. <https://twitter.com/DRMacIver/status/1291044809621360641>

text: <@U8A5MS6R1> Love to hear your thoughts on what you'd like to see from an ideal way for people to share ideas, especially if it's inspired by the Mother of All Demos, which I understand to be mainly about real-time collaboration. I sort of put collaboration and sharing ideas in different buckets, perhaps those lines could be blurred?

elements.text: Love to hear your thoughts on what you'd like to see from an ideal way for people to share ideas, especially if it's inspired by the Mother of All Demos, which I understand to be mainly about real-time collaboration. I sort of put collaboration and sharing ideas in different buckets, perhaps those lines could be blurred?

text:
For starters at least drawing a little picture should be as easy as typing some text. I've got ~4K~ 2 million pixels, a touchscreen, even a stylus sitting in front of me, and here I am explaining the picture in my head using ~26 buttons.

Really any computation related idea would be live and executable 'inline'. E.g. not "heres a demo video" or "here's a link to the software you can download, configure, fix all the build/install errors and perhaps then run". But rather "heres a demo video you can pause, rewinde and takeover to play with the system to take it elsewhere." Also, the virtual visual medium should be annotate-able. While watching the live executable/video, I want to pause, circle a part and type a comment and start a thread. I also want to be able to view/change the source right there (fork it live!) to try out an idea. Then other folks can view the annotation, try out my change etc.

I mentioned the Mother of All Demos because that inspired a lot of ideas about a shared collaborative space, not specifically for ideas *in* the demo itself.

text:
Ok so I'm going back to a hypothesis that someone fed all of Kay's quora answers (and more) to GPT-3. However, I really didn't think GPT-3 could make a joke like this: <https://twitter.com/NotAlanKay/status/1282745357504442368>

So maybe it's a _human augmented machine_. Ironic?

text:
<https://www.quantamagazine.org/the-brain-maps-out-ideas-and-memories-like-spaces-20190114/|https://www.quantamagazine.org/the-brain-maps-out-ideas-and-memories-like-spaces-20190114/>
> Our language is riddled with spatial metaphors for reasoning, and for memory in general
> 
> Grid cells provide a longer-range coordinate system for determining position in the absence of external cues. Researchers think the brain may use a similar system to navigate through mental "spaces" of abstract knowledge and memory.

attachments.title: The Brain Maps Out Ideas and Memories Like Spaces | Quanta Magazine
attachments.text: Emerging evidence suggests that the brain encodes abstract knowledge in the same way that it represents positions in space, which hints at a more universal theory of cognition.
attachments.fallback: Quanta Magazine: The Brain Maps Out Ideas and Memories Like Spaces | Quanta Magazine

elements.text: https://www.quantamagazine.org/the-brain-maps-out-ideas-and-memories-like-spaces-20190114/

Our language is riddled with spatial metaphors for reasoning, and for memory in general

Grid cells provide a longer-range coordinate system for determining position in the absence of external cues. Researchers think the brain may use a similar system to navigate through mental "spaces" of abstract knowledge and memory.

text:
Does anyone know of interesting projects or research re. keeping product documentation (esp. structured to correspond with a UI) is sync with codebase changes?

My mind goes to docstring-and-docstring-adjacent tools for documenting code, but documenting code for reuse seems like a distinct task from generating product documentation for a nontechnical reader.
